Garnish with cilantro and ginger julienne. Serve hot with naan.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Awadhi slow-cooked stew. The meat should be falling off the bone. Long cooking time is essential. Perfect for special occasions.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak rice for 30 minutes. Marinate mutton in yogurt and spices for 1 hour. Heat ghee and add whole spices. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and marinated mutton. Cook for 10 minutes. Layer half the rice over mutton. Add fried onions, cashews, and raisins. Layer remaining rice. Soak saffron in warm milk and drizzle over rice. Cover tightly and cook on low heat for 25 minutes. Let rest for 10 minutes before serving.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Mughlai biryani with mutton. The rice should be perfectly cooked and aromatic. Don't stir after layering. Let it rest before serving.

ingredients: For Filling: 1 cup boiled and mashed potatoes
Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix flour, semolina, ghee, salt, and sugar. Add warm water to make soft dough. Rest for 30 minutes. For filling, mix potatoes, paneer, chilies, and spices. Heat ghee and add to filling. Divide dough into balls. Roll each ball and place filling in center. Seal edges and shape into oval. Steam for 20 minutes until cooked. Serve hot with ghee.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Himachali steamed bread. The dough should be soft and pliable. Don't overfill to prevent breaking. Perfect with local chutneys.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Dry roast cumin, coriander, and fennel seeds. Grind to powder. Heat mustard oil and add red chilies. Add potatoes and cook for 5 minutes. Add ground spices, turmeric, and chili powder. Cook for 10 minutes until potatoes are crispy. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with roti.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kumaoni potato dish. Mustard oil gives authentic flavor. Potatoes should be crispy on outside. Perfect mountain food.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook kidney beans with turmeric and salt for 3 whistles. Cook rice separately. Heat oil and add cumin seeds. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and tomato puree. Add spices and cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked beans and simmer for 20 minutes. Season with salt and garam masala. Serve hot rajma with rice. Garnish with cilantro.
Indian.chef_tips: Classic Dogri comfort food. The rajma should be thick and creamy. Perfect with steamed rice. Traditional Jammu cuisine.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Boil mustard greens, spinach, and bathua until tender. Blend to smooth paste. Heat ghee and add cumin seeds. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and chilies. Add spices and cook for 5 minutes. Add blended greens and simmer for 20 minutes. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with makki ki roti.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Punjabi winter dish. The greens should be well-cooked and smooth. Perfect with corn bread. Seasonal specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak ker and sangri overnight. Boil until tender. Heat oil and add cumin seeds. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and tomatoes. Add spices and cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked ker and sangri. Simmer for 15 minutes. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with roti.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Rajasthani desert dish. Ker and sangri are unique desert ingredients. Perfect for dry regions. Authentic local cuisine.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Dry roast fennel, cumin, and coriander seeds. Grind to powder. Heat ghee and add whole spices. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and lamb. Brown lamb on all sides. Add yogurt and ground spices. Cook for 10 minutes. Add water and simmer for 1 hour until lamb is tender. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kashmiri lamb curry. The meat should be tender and flavorful. Long cooking time is essential. Perfect for special occasions.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix minced lamb with papaya paste and spices. Marinate for 2 hours. Heat ghee and add onions. Cook until golden and crispy. Remove and set aside. Shape lamb mixture into flat patties. Cook on tawa until golden brown on both sides. Serve hot with crispy onions and lemon wedges. Garnish with cilantro.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Awadhi royal kebab. The papaya paste tenderizes the meat. Don't overmix to keep texture. Perfect for special occasions.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Cut bread into triangles. Deep fry in ghee until golden. Make sugar syrup with water and sugar. Boil cream with milk and cardamom. Soak saffron in warm milk. Dip fried bread in sugar syrup. Arrange on plate. Pour cream mixture over bread. Garnish with nuts, raisins, and saffron. Drizzle rose water. Serve chilled.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Mughlai royal dessert. The bread should be crispy but not hard. Perfect balance of sweetness. Royal presentation.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook chickpeas with turmeric and salt for 3 whistles. Heat ghee and add cumin seeds. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and yogurt. Add spices and cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked chickpeas and cream. Simmer for 20 minutes. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Himachali chickpea curry. The yogurt and cream give it richness. Perfect with steamed rice. Mountain cuisine specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook soybeans with turmeric and salt for 3 whistles. Heat oil and add cumin seeds. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and tomatoes. Add spices and cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked soybeans and simmer for 15 minutes. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kumaoni soybean curry. The beans should be tender and flavorful. Perfect protein-rich mountain food. Local specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook lentils with turmeric and salt for 3 whistles. Heat ghee and add cumin seeds. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and tomato puree. Add spices and cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked lentils and simmer for 20 minutes. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Classic Dogri comfort food. The dal should be creamy and well-seasoned. Perfect with steamed rice. Traditional home cooking.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix corn flour, wheat flour, and salt. Add warm water gradually to make soft dough. Rest for 10 minutes. Divide into balls. Roll each ball into thin circle using extra flour. Cook on tawa until golden spots appear. Flip and cook other side. Apply ghee on both sides. Serve hot with sarson da saag.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Punjabi corn bread. The dough should be soft but not sticky. Don't over-roll to prevent breaking. Perfect with mustard greens.

ingredients: For Dal: 1/2 cup split yellow lentils
Indian.cooking_instructions: For Baati: Mix flour, semolina, ghee, and salt. Add warm water to make stiff dough. Shape into balls and bake at 350°F for 25 minutes. For Dal: Pressure cook lentils with turmeric and salt for 3 whistles. Heat ghee and add cumin seeds. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and tomato puree. Add spices and cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked lentils and simmer for 20 minutes. Season with salt and garam masala. Serve hot dal with baati.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Rajasthani complete meal. The baati should be hard and crispy. The dal should be thick and flavorful. Perfect desert cuisine.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak rice for 30 minutes. Dry roast fennel, cumin, and coriander seeds. Grind to powder. Heat ghee and add whole spices. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and mutton. Brown mutton on all sides. Add yogurt and ground spices. Cook for 10 minutes. Add rice and water. Cover and cook on low heat for 20 minutes. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kashmiri mutton pulao. The rice should be perfectly cooked and aromatic. Don't stir after adding rice. Let it rest before serving.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Fry sliced onions until golden and grind to paste. Grind soaked cashews to smooth paste. Heat ghee and add whole spices. Add chicken and cook for 5 minutes. Add yogurt, onion paste, and cashew paste. Add all spices and cook for 10 minutes. Add cream and simmer for 30 minutes until chicken is tender. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with naan.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Awadhi royal curry. The onion paste gives the dish its signature sweetness. Cashews add richness and creaminess. Cook on low heat to prevent curdling.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix flour, yogurt, water, salt, and sugar. Add ghee and knead into soft dough. Rest for 2 hours. Divide into balls. Roll each ball into oval shape. Sprinkle nigella seeds and press gently. Cook on tawa until golden spots appear. Flip and cook other side. Apply ghee on both sides. Serve hot with curry.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Mughlai bread. The dough should be soft and pliable. Don't over-roll to prevent breaking. Perfect with rich curries.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak all lentils overnight. Pressure cook with turmeric and salt for 3 whistles. Heat ghee and add cumin seeds. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and tomato puree. Add spices and cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked lentils and simmer for 30 minutes. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Himachali festival dish. The lentils should be well-cooked and flavorful. Perfect for special occasions. Mountain cuisine specialty.

ingredients: For Filling: 3 medium potatoes, boiled and mashed
Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix flour, water, salt, and oil to make soft dough. Rest for 30 minutes. For filling, mix potatoes, onions, chilies, and spices. Divide dough into balls. Roll each ball and place filling in center. Seal edges and roll into circle. Cook on tawa until golden spots appear. Flip and cook other side. Apply ghee on both sides. Serve hot with yogurt.
Indian.chef_tips: Classic Punjabi stuffed bread. The dough should be soft and pliable. Don't overfill to prevent breaking. Perfect for breakfast or lunch.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix flour with ghee and water to make thin batter. Heat oil and pour batter in circular motion to create lacy pattern. Deep fry until golden and crispy. Make sugar syrup with water and sugar. Boil cream with cardamom. Soak ghevar in sugar syrup. Arrange on plate. Pour cream mixture over ghevar. Garnish with nuts and raisins. Serve chilled.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Rajasthani festival sweet. The batter should be thin and smooth. Perfect lacy pattern is key. Royal dessert specialty.

ingredients: 1/2 cup mixed dry fruits (almonds, cashews, raisins)
Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak rice for 30 minutes. Soak saffron in warm milk. Heat ghee and add dry fruits. Cook until golden. Add rice and cook for 5 minutes. Add sugar, cardamom, and saffron milk. Add water and cover. Cook on low heat for 20 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kashmiri sweet pulao. The rice should be perfectly cooked and aromatic. Don't stir after adding water. Let it rest before serving.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix minced lamb with papaya paste and spices. Marinate for 2 hours. Heat ghee and add onions. Cook until golden and crispy. Remove and set aside. Shape lamb mixture around skewers. Grill until golden brown on all sides. Serve hot with crispy onions and lemon wedges. Garnish with cilantro.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Awadhi royal kebab. The papaya paste tenderizes the meat. Don't overmix to keep texture. Perfect for special occasions.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak saffron in warm milk. Boil milk with cream and sugar until reduced by half. Add saffron milk and cardamom. Add nuts and raisins. Cook until thick. Pour into kulfi molds. Freeze for 6 hours. Serve chilled.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Mughlai frozen dessert. The milk should be reduced to half. Perfect balance of sweetness. Royal dessert specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook chickpeas with turmeric and salt for 3 whistles. Heat ghee and add cumin seeds. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and yogurt. Add spices and cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked chickpeas and cream. Simmer for 20 minutes. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Himachali chickpea curry. The yogurt and cream give it richness. Perfect with steamed rice. Mountain cuisine specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook soybeans with turmeric and salt for 3 whistles. Heat ghee and add cumin seeds. Add onions and cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and yogurt. Add spices and cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked soybeans and simmer for 20 minutes. Season with salt and garam masala. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kumaoni soybean curry. The beans should be tender and flavorful. Perfect protein-rich mountain food. Local specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix flour, yogurt, water, salt, and sugar. Add ghee and knead into soft dough. Rest for 2 hours. Divide into balls. Roll each ball into oval shape. Sprinkle nigella seeds and press gently. Cook on tawa until golden spots appear. Flip and cook other side. Apply ghee on both sides. Serve hot with curry.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Dogri bread. The dough should be soft and pliable. Don't over-roll to prevent breaking. Perfect with rich curries.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix besan, semolina, yogurt, water, ginger-chili paste, lemon juice, sugar, turmeric, and salt. Let batter rest for 10 minutes. Add eno and mix gently. Pour into greased steamer plate. Steam for 15 minutes. For tempering, heat oil and add mustard seeds, sesame seeds, chilies, and curry leaves. Pour over dhokla. Cut into pieces and garnish with cilantro. Serve with green chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Gujarati steamed snack. The batter should be smooth and lump-free. Don't overmix after adding eno. Perfect for breakfast or tea time.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix flour, fenugreek leaves, yogurt, ginger-chili paste, all spices, salt, and oil. Add water gradually to make soft dough. Rest for 15 minutes. Divide into balls. Roll each ball into thin circle. Cook on tawa until golden spots appear on both sides. Apply oil if needed. Serve hot with pickle and yogurt.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Gujarati flatbread. The dough should be soft and pliable. Fresh fenugreek leaves give the best flavor. Perfect travel food.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix besan with water, ginger-chili paste, lemon juice, sugar, turmeric, and salt. Beat well to make smooth batter. Add eno and mix gently. Pour into greased steamer plate. Steam for 12 minutes. For tempering, heat oil and add mustard seeds, chilies, and curry leaves. Pour over khaman. Garnish with coconut and cilantro. Cut into pieces and serve.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Gujarati steamed snack. The batter should be lump-free and aerated. Don't overmix after adding eno. Lighter version of dhokla.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Roast peanuts, sesame seeds, and coconut. Grind with coriander and cumin seeds. Mix with spices and salt to make stuffing. Stuff eggplant and potatoes with this mixture. Heat oil in pot and arrange all vegetables. Cover and cook on low heat for 45 minutes, stirring occasionally. Season with salt. Serve hot with puri.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Gujarati winter vegetable medley. Each vegetable should be perfectly cooked. The stuffing is the key to authentic flavor. Festival specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak rice and lentils for 4 hours. Grind to coarse paste with yogurt. Add ginger-chili paste, vegetables, spices, and salt. Let batter ferment for 6 hours. Add eno and mix. Heat oil in pan and add tempering ingredients. Pour batter and cover. Cook for 30 minutes on low heat. Cut into pieces and serve with chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Gujarati savory cake. The batter should be well-fermented for best taste. Cook on low heat for even cooking. Perfect breakfast dish.

ingredients: For Filling: 1 cup split yellow lentils, cooked
Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook lentils until soft. Mash and cook with jaggery until thick. Add cardamom and nutmeg. Cool completely. Make dough with flour, salt, oil, and water. Rest for 30 minutes. Divide dough and filling into equal portions. Roll dough, place filling, seal, and roll carefully. Cook on tawa until golden spots appear. Apply ghee and serve hot.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Maharashtrian sweet flatbread. The filling should be completely cool before using. Roll carefully to prevent breaking. Festival specialty.

ingredients: For Vada: 3 medium potatoes, boiled and mashed
Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat oil and add mustard seeds and curry leaves. Add ginger-chili paste, potatoes, turmeric, and salt. Mix well and make balls. Make batter with besan, water, turmeric, and salt. Dip potato balls in batter and deep fry until golden. Slit pav, apply chutneys, place vada, and serve hot with fried green chilies.
Indian.chef_tips: Mumbai's iconic street food. The vada should be crispy outside and soft inside. Fresh pav is essential. Serve immediately for best taste.

ingredients: For Garnish: Chopped onions, tomatoes, cilantro
Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook sprouts with turmeric and salt for 2 whistles. Heat oil and add onions. Cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, and all spices. Cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked sprouts and simmer for 15 minutes. Adjust consistency with water. Serve hot with pav and garnishes.
Indian.chef_tips: Popular Maharashtrian breakfast dish. The sprouts should be well-cooked but not mushy. Misal masala is key to authentic flavor. Spicy and nutritious.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat coconut oil and add onions. Cook until translucent. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, curry powder, turmeric, and green chilies. Cook for 5 minutes. Add thin coconut milk and tamarind paste. Simmer for 5 minutes. Add fish pieces and thick coconut milk. Cook for 8 minutes until fish is done. Add curry leaves and season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Goan coastal curry. Use fresh fish for best results. Don't overcook fish to prevent breaking. Coconut milk should not boil vigorously.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak red chilies in warm water for 30 minutes. Grind chilies with cumin, peppercorns, cloves, cinnamon, garlic, ginger, and vinegar to make paste. Marinate pork with this paste for 2 hours. Heat coconut oil and add onions. Cook until golden. Add marinated pork and cook for 10 minutes. Add jaggery and salt. Cover and cook for 1 hour until pork is tender. Serve with rice or bread.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Goan Portuguese-influenced curry. The longer marination gives better flavor. Use palm vinegar for authentic taste. Spicy and tangy.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix flour with coconut milk to make smooth batter. Melt jaggery with little water to make syrup. Cool and add to batter with egg yolks, nutmeg, and cardamom. Heat ghee and add to batter. Pour one layer in greased baking dish and bake until golden. Add next layer and repeat until all batter is used (7-10 layers). Each layer should be golden before adding next. Cool completely before cutting. Garnish with almonds.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Goan Christmas dessert. Each layer must be perfectly baked. Patience is key for authentic bebinca. Royal Portuguese-influenced sweet.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak rice for 4 hours. Grind rice with coconut and water to make thin batter. Add salt. Heat non-stick pan and pour thin layer of batter. Cover and cook for 2 minutes until edges lift. Don't flip. Remove carefully and fold. Serve hot with coconut chutney or curry.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Konkani crepe. The batter should be very thin and smooth. Cook on one side only. Delicate and requires practice.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat coconut oil and add mustard seeds. Add curry leaves and green chilies. Add vegetables and turmeric. Cook for 5 minutes. Add thin coconut milk and tamarind paste. Simmer for 10 minutes. Add thick coconut milk and salt. Cook for 5 more minutes. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Konkani coconut curry. Don't boil after adding thick coconut milk. Fresh vegetables give the best flavor. Coastal specialty.

ingredients: For Curry: 1 cup thick coconut milk
Indian.cooking_instructions: For Vade: Mix flours, salt, oil, and water to make stiff dough. Rest for 30 minutes. Roll into circles and deep fry until puffed. For Curry: Heat coconut oil and add onions. Cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, and Malvani masala. Cook for 5 minutes. Add chicken and cook for 10 minutes. Add coconut milk and curry leaves. Simmer for 20 minutes. Season with salt. Serve hot chicken curry with vade.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Malvani coastal dish. Malvani masala is key to authentic flavor. Vade should be crispy and puffed. Seafood coastal cuisine.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak kokum in water for 30 minutes. Extract juice and strain. Mix kokum juice with coconut milk. Add ginger, green chilies, and salt. Mix well. Garnish with cilantro. Serve chilled as digestive drink.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Malvani digestive drink. Kokum gives the drink its pink color and tangy flavor. Perfect after spicy meals. Coastal refresher.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook mutton with lentils and vegetables for 4 whistles. Mash lightly. Heat oil and add onions. Cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, and dhansak masala. Cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked mutton-lentil mixture and tamarind paste. Simmer for 30 minutes until thick. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve with brown rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Parsi Sunday lunch. The lentils should be well-mashed but mutton pieces intact. Dhansak masala is essential. Sweet-sour-spicy combination.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat ghee and add onions. Cook until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, and all spices. Cook for 5 minutes. Add mutton and cook for 10 minutes. Cover and cook for 45 minutes until mutton is tender. Season with salt. Garnish with potato straws and cilantro. Serve hot with bread.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Parsi mutton curry. The onions should be well-browned for deep flavor. Crispy potato straws on top are signature. Rich and flavorful.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Grind coconut, cilantro, mint, green chilies, ginger-garlic paste, lemon juice, and salt to make green chutney. Coat fish fillets with this chutney. Wrap each fillet in banana leaf and tie with string. Steam for 20 minutes until fish is cooked. Serve hot in banana leaf parcels.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Parsi steamed fish. Banana leaves impart unique flavor. The green chutney should be thick. Healthy steamed preparation.

Indian.cooking_instructions: For Fafda: Mix besan, oil, ajwain, turmeric, salt, and water to make stiff dough. Rest for 30 minutes. Roll into thin strips and deep fry until crispy. For Jalebi: Mix flour, yogurt, and baking powder. Ferment for 8 hours. Make sugar syrup with water, saffron, and cardamom. Fill batter in squeeze bottle and make spirals in hot oil. Fry until golden and dip in syrup. Serve fafda with jalebi.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Gujarati breakfast combination. Fafda should be crispy and jalebi should be juicy. Perfect sweet-savory combination. Festival favorite.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix besan with buttermilk, ginger-chili paste, turmeric, and salt. Cook on low heat, stirring continuously until thick. Spread on greased surface and cool. Cut into strips and roll. For tempering, heat oil and add mustard seeds, sesame seeds, chilies, and curry leaves. Pour over khandvi. Garnish with coconut and cilantro.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Gujarati rolled snack. Continuous stirring is essential to prevent lumps. The batter should be smooth and glossy. Requires skill and practice.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat oil and add mashed potatoes, dabeli masala, and salt. Cook for 5 minutes. Slit pav and apply green chutney and tamarind chutney. Fill with potato mixture. Top with onions, peanuts, sev, and pomegranate seeds. Toast on tawa until golden. Serve hot.
Indian.chef_tips: Popular Gujarati street food from Kutch. The potato filling should be well-spiced. Fresh garnishes are essential. Sweet and tangy flavors.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Wash rice and lentils together. Heat ghee and add cumin seeds, cloves, and cinnamon. Add ginger-chili paste and curry leaves. Add rice, lentils, water, turmeric, and salt. Pressure cook for 3 whistles. Let pressure release naturally. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with pickle and papad.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Gujarati comfort food. The consistency should be soft and porridge-like. Perfect for sick days. Simple and nutritious.

ingredients: Fresh cilantro and lemon for garnish
Indian.cooking_instructions: Rinse poha in water and drain. Heat oil and add mustard seeds. Add curry leaves, onions, green chilies, and ginger. Cook for 2 minutes. Add peanuts, turmeric, salt, and sugar. Add poha and mix gently. Cook for 3 minutes. Garnish with cilantro and lemon juice. Serve hot.
Indian.chef_tips: Popular Maharashtrian breakfast dish. Don't wash poha too much to prevent mushiness. The texture should be soft but not sticky. Quick and healthy.

Indian.cooking_instructions: In a large bowl, mix puffed rice with onions, tomatoes, and peanuts. Add tamarind chutney, green chutney, and chaat masala. Mix well. Top with sev and cilantro. Add lemon juice. Serve immediately.
Indian.chef_tips: Mumbai's iconic street snack. Serve immediately to maintain crispiness. Balance of sweet, sour, and spicy flavors is key. Fresh ingredients essential.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix all flours with onions, chilies, ginger-garlic paste, cilantro, spices, salt, and oil. Add water gradually to make soft dough. Rest for 15 minutes. Take portions and spread on tawa with wet hands. Make holes with finger and cook until golden on both sides. Serve hot with yogurt and pickle.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Maharashtrian multigrain flatbread. Use wet hands to spread evenly. The holes help in even cooking. Nutritious and filling.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Beat eggs with salt. Heat butter and add onions. Cook until translucent. Add ginger-garlic paste, green chilies, and tomatoes. Cook for 3 minutes. Add turmeric and beaten eggs. Scramble gently until just set. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with buttered toast.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Parsi scrambled eggs. Don't overcook to keep eggs creamy. The vegetables should be well-cooked. Perfect for breakfast or brunch.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Beat eggs with sugar until frothy. Heat milk and add cardamom and nutmeg. Cool slightly and add to beaten eggs. Strain mixture. Grease baking dish with ghee. Add almonds and raisins to dish. Pour custard mixture over them. Steam for 30 minutes until set. Cool completely before serving.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Parsi wedding dessert. Steam cooking gives unique texture. Don't overbake to prevent curdling. Served at special occasions.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Roast besan in ghee until fragrant and golden. Make sugar syrup with milk until one-string consistency. Add roasted besan to syrup and mix quickly. Add cardamom, saffron, and half the nuts. Pour into greased plate and spread evenly. Garnish with remaining nuts. Cool completely and cut into pieces.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Gujarati sweet. Roast besan properly for best flavor. Work quickly after adding syrup. Perfect for festivals and celebrations.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak saffron in warm milk. Whisk hung yogurt until smooth. Add powdered sugar, cardamom, and saffron milk. Mix well until sugar dissolves. Garnish with chopped nuts. Chill for 2 hours before serving.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Gujarati sweetened yogurt. Yogurt should be well-hung and thick. Adjust sugar to taste. Perfect summer dessert.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak kokum in water for 30 minutes. Extract juice and strain. Mix kokum juice with coconut milk. Add ginger, green chilies, and salt. Mix well. Garnish with cilantro. Serve chilled as digestive drink.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Maharashtrian digestive drink. Kokum gives the drink its pink color and tangy flavor. Perfect after spicy meals. Coastal refresher.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat coconut oil and add onions. Cook until translucent. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, curry powder, turmeric, and green chilies. Cook for 5 minutes. Add thin coconut milk and tamarind paste. Simmer for 5 minutes. Add prawns and thick coconut milk. Cook for 5 minutes until prawns are done. Add curry leaves and season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Goan coastal curry. Use fresh prawns for best results. Don't overcook prawns to prevent toughness. Coconut milk should not boil vigorously.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook pigeon peas with turmeric for 3 whistles. Cook vegetables separately. Heat coconut oil and add mustard seeds, urad dal, red chilies, and curry leaves. Add asafoetida and sambar powder. Add cooked dal, vegetables, tamarind paste, and salt. Simmer for 10 minutes. Garnish with cilantro. Serve with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Tamil lentil curry. The consistency should be thin like soup. Fresh vegetables give the best flavor. Essential part of South Indian meals.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat ghee and add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, red chilies, and curry leaves. Add tomatoes and cook until soft. Add tamarind paste, rasam powder, turmeric, asafoetida, and water. Boil for 10 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot as soup or with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Tamil tangy soup. The flavor should be sour and spicy. Don't boil too long after adding tamarind. Perfect digestive after meals.

ingredients: 3 cups dosa batter (fermented rice and lentil)
Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat dosa tawa and grease with oil. Pour a ladle of batter and spread in circular motion to make thin crepe. Drizzle oil around edges. Cook until golden and crispy. Fold and serve hot with sambar and chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Tamil crepe. The batter should be well-fermented. Spread batter quickly for thin dosa. Practice makes perfect.

ingredients: 2 cups idli batter (fermented rice and lentil)
Indian.cooking_instructions: Grease idli plates with oil. Pour batter into each mold. Steam for 10 minutes until cooked. Remove with wet cloth. Serve hot with sambar and chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Tamil steamed cake. The batter should be well-fermented and fluffy. Steam on high heat. Healthy and nutritious breakfast.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat coconut oil and add fenugreek seeds. Add onions and cook until translucent. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, curry powder, turmeric, and green chilies. Cook for 5 minutes. Add thin coconut milk and tamarind paste. Simmer for 5 minutes. Add fish pieces and thick coconut milk. Cook for 8 minutes until fish is done. Add curry leaves and season with salt. Serve with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kerala coastal curry. Clay pot gives authentic flavor. Use fresh fish for best results. Don't overcook fish.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Grind coconut with little water. Mix rice flour with coconut paste, coconut milk, yeast, sugar, salt, and water to make smooth batter. Ferment for 8 hours. Heat appam pan and grease with oil. Pour batter and swirl to coat sides. Cover and cook for 3 minutes until edges are crispy and center is soft. Serve hot with stew or curry.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kerala fermented pancake. The batter should be well-fermented. Cook in special appam pan for authentic shape. Soft center with crispy edges.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix rice flour with salt and water to make crumbly mixture. Layer coconut and rice flour mixture in puttu maker. Steam for 10 minutes until cooked. Remove carefully and serve hot with banana and jaggery or curry.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kerala steamed rice cake. The rice flour should be just moist, not wet. Layer properly for even cooking. Breakfast specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook rice and dal together with turmeric for 3 whistles. Cook vegetables separately. Heat ghee and add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, red chilies, and curry leaves. Add bisi bele bath powder and cooked rice-dal mixture. Add vegetables, tamarind paste, peanuts, and salt. Simmer for 15 minutes. Serve hot with ghee.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Karnataka one-pot meal. The consistency should be thick like khichdi. Bisi bele bath powder is essential. Comfort food from Karnataka.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Roast besan in 2 tbsp ghee until fragrant. Make sugar syrup with water until one-string consistency. Add roasted besan to syrup and mix quickly. Add remaining ghee gradually while stirring. Add cashews. Pour into greased plate when mixture thickens. Cool completely and cut into pieces.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Karnataka sweet from Mysore. Timing is crucial for perfect texture. Add ghee gradually for best results. Royal sweet of Karnataka.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak rice for 30 minutes. Marinate mutton in yogurt, garlic, ginger, and spices for 1 hour. Heat ghee and add onions. Cook until golden. Add marinated mutton and cook for 15 minutes. Layer half the rice over mutton. Add fried onions, cashews, and raisins. Layer remaining rice. Soak saffron in warm milk and drizzle over rice. Cover tightly and cook on low heat for 30 minutes. Let rest for 10 minutes before serving.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Andhra biryani with mutton. The spice level is higher than other biryanis. Don't stir after layering. Spicy and flavorful.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Clean and chop gongura leaves. Heat oil and add onions. Cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste and mutton. Cook for 10 minutes. Add all spices and cook for 5 minutes. Add gongura leaves and mix well. Cover and cook for 45 minutes until mutton is tender. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Andhra sour curry. Gongura leaves give unique tangy flavor. Cook until mutton is very tender. Signature dish of Andhra Pradesh.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak wheat and lentils for 4 hours. Pressure cook mutton with ginger-garlic paste for 6 whistles. Cook wheat and lentils separately until very soft. Mash everything together until smooth paste. Heat ghee and add onions. Cook until golden. Add spices and cooked mutton mixture. Simmer for 1 hour, stirring frequently. Season with salt. Garnish with fried onions and mint. Serve with lemon wedges.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Hyderabadi Ramadan specialty. The mixture should be smooth and porridge-like. Continuous stirring is essential. Labor-intensive but worth it.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Cook ash gourd in thin coconut milk until tender. Add cooked black-eyed peas and green chilies. Simmer for 5 minutes. Add thick coconut milk and curry leaves. Season with salt. Heat coconut oil and pour over olan. Serve as part of sadya meal.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kerala festival dish. Don't boil after adding thick coconut milk. Simple and subtle flavors. Essential part of Onam sadya.

ingredients: 2 cups mixed vegetables (drumsticks, carrots, beans, plantain)
Indian.cooking_instructions: Cut vegetables into long strips. Cook vegetables until tender. Grind coconut with green chilies and cumin. Add coconut paste to vegetables. Add yogurt and curry leaves. Simmer for 5 minutes. Season with salt. Heat coconut oil and pour over avial. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kerala mixed vegetable curry. Vegetables should be cut uniformly. Don't overcook vegetables. Classic Kerala comfort food.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat coconut oil and add onions. Cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, and all spices. Cook for 5 minutes. Add chicken pieces and cook for 10 minutes. Add Chettinad masala and curry leaves. Cover and cook for 25 minutes until chicken is tender. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Chettinad spicy chicken. The masala powder is key to authentic flavor. Use coconut oil for best taste. Very spicy and flavorful.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Boil water with salt. Add ragi flour gradually while stirring to avoid lumps. Cook until thick dough forms. Knead well and shape into balls. Serve hot with sambar or curry.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Karnataka staple food. The consistency should be firm but not hard. Nutritious finger millet dish. Eaten with hands traditionally.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak green gram and rice for 4 hours. Grind with green chilies, ginger, cumin, curry leaves, and salt to make batter. Heat pan and pour batter to make thick pancake. Drizzle oil around edges. Cook until golden on both sides. Serve hot with ginger chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Andhra green gram pancake. The batter should be thick but spreadable. High in protein. Popular breakfast dish.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat coconut oil and add onions. Cook until translucent. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, turmeric, and green chilies. Cook for 5 minutes. Add thin coconut milk and simmer for 5 minutes. Add fish pieces and thick coconut milk. Cook for 8 minutes until fish is done. Add curry leaves and lemon juice. Season with salt. Serve with appam or rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kerala mild fish curry. Don't boil coconut milk vigorously. The curry should be creamy white. Mild and aromatic.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak lentils for 2 hours. Grind coarsely with green chilies, ginger, curry leaves, and salt. Don't add water while grinding. Heat oil and wet hands. Shape batter into donuts and deep fry until golden. Serve hot with sambar and chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Tamil fried donuts. The batter should be coarse, not smooth. Don't add water while grinding. Crispy outside, soft inside.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Roast semolina until light golden. Heat oil and add mustard seeds, urad dal, green chilies, ginger, curry leaves, and cashews. Add roasted semolina and mix. Cool completely. Add yogurt, water, and salt. Mix well and rest for 10 minutes. Add eno and mix gently. Pour into greased idli molds and steam for 12 minutes. Serve with chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Karnataka instant idli variation. Semolina should be well-roasted. Don't overmix after adding eno. Quick alternative to traditional idli.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak rice for 4 hours. Grind rice with coconut and water to make very thin batter. Add salt. Heat non-stick pan and pour thin layer of batter. Cover and cook for 2 minutes until edges lift. Don't flip. Remove carefully and fold. Serve hot with coconut chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Tulu coastal crepe. The batter should be extremely thin and smooth. Cook on one side only. Delicate and lacy texture.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat coconut oil and add onions. Cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, and all spices. Cook for 5 minutes. Add pork pieces and cook for 15 minutes. Add Kodava masala, tamarind paste, and curry leaves. Cover and cook for 40 minutes until pork is tender. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kodava pork curry from Coorg. The Kodava masala is essential for authentic flavor. Use coconut oil for best taste. Rich and spicy.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Cook rice in milk until very soft. Mash rice and cook until creamy. Add jaggery and cook until dissolved. Add coconut and cardamom. Heat ghee and fry cashews and raisins. Add to payasam. Simmer for 5 minutes. Serve hot or cold.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kerala sweet rice pudding. The rice should be well-cooked and creamy. Perfect for festivals and celebrations. Can be served hot or cold.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook rice and lentils with water for 3 whistles. Mash well. Add milk and cook until creamy. Add jaggery and cardamom. Heat ghee and fry cashews and raisins. Add to pongal. Mix well and serve hot.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Tamil harvest festival dish. The consistency should be creamy like kheer. Perfect balance of sweet and creamy. Festival specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook dal with turmeric for 3 whistles. Mash well. Clean and chop gongura leaves. Heat oil and add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, red chilies, and curry leaves. Add gongura leaves and green chilies. Cook for 5 minutes. Add cooked dal, tamarind paste, and salt. Simmer for 10 minutes. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Andhra tangy dal. Gongura leaves give unique sour flavor. Don't overcook the leaves. Perfect with steamed rice.

ingredients: For Filling: 1 cup split Bengal gram, cooked
Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook Bengal gram until soft. Mash and cook with jaggery until thick. Add cardamom. Cool completely. Make dough with flour, salt, oil, and water. Rest for 30 minutes. Divide dough and filling into portions. Roll dough, place filling, seal, and roll carefully. Cook on tawa until golden spots appear. Apply ghee and serve hot.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Karnataka sweet flatbread. The filling should be completely cool before using. Roll carefully to prevent breaking. Festival delicacy.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Make sugar syrup with water until one-string consistency. Mix wheat flour with little water to make smooth paste. Add flour paste to sugar syrup and cook, stirring continuously. Add ghee gradually while stirring. Add cardamom and food coloring. Cook until mixture thickens and leaves sides of pan. Add cashews and raisins. Pour into greased plate and cool. Cut into pieces.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kerala sweet from Kozhikode. Continuous stirring is essential. The texture should be smooth and glossy. Famous Malabar delicacy.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak lentils for 3 hours. Grind coarsely with green chilies, ginger, curry leaves, asafoetida, and salt. Don't add water while grinding. Beat batter for 5 minutes to make fluffy. Heat oil and wet hands. Shape batter into donuts with hole in center. Deep fry until golden brown. Serve hot with sambar and chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Tamil fried lentil donuts. The batter should be fluffy and well-aerated. Don't add water while grinding. Perfect breakfast item.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Slit green chilies lengthwise and remove seeds. Mix besan, rice flour, chili powder, turmeric, and salt. Add water to make thick batter. Dip chilies in batter and deep fry until golden and crispy. Serve hot with coconut chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Popular Andhra street snack. Remove seeds to reduce heat. The batter should coat chilies well. Perfect monsoon snack.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Cook pumpkin with turmeric until tender. Grind coconut with green chilies and cumin. Add coconut paste to cooked pumpkin. Add black-eyed peas and curry leaves. Simmer for 5 minutes. Season with salt. Heat coconut oil and pour over erissery. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Kerala pumpkin curry. The coconut paste should be coarse. Don't overcook vegetables. Onam sadya essential.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat mustard oil and add panch phoron and bay leaf. Add onions and cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, and all spices. Cook for 5 minutes. Add fish pieces and green chilies. Cook for 10 minutes until fish is done. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali fish curry. Mustard oil gives authentic flavor. Use fresh river fish for best taste. Don't overcook fish.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Boil milk until reduced to half. Add jaggery and cardamom. Cool to lukewarm. Add yogurt and mix well. Pour into clay pots. Keep in warm place for 6-8 hours to set. Refrigerate before serving. Serve chilled.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali sweet yogurt. Clay pots give authentic flavor. The milk should be well-reduced. Perfect dessert for hot weather.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix flour, salt, and ghee. Add water gradually to make soft dough. Rest for 30 minutes. Divide into balls and roll into thin circles. Deep fry in hot oil until puffed and golden. Serve hot with curry or dal.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali deep-fried bread. The dough should be soft and pliable. Fry on high heat for best puffing. Serve immediately.

ingredients: 1 elephant apple (ou tenga) or lemon juice
Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat mustard oil and add onions. Cook until translucent. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, turmeric, and green chilies. Cook for 5 minutes. Add fish pieces and cook for 8 minutes. Add elephant apple or lemon juice. Simmer for 5 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Assamese sour fish curry. Elephant apple gives unique tangy flavor. Use local river fish for authenticity. Light and refreshing.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Pressure cook dal with vegetables, ginger, turmeric, and green chilies for 3 whistles. Mash lightly. Heat ghee and add cumin seeds, mustard seeds, red chilies, and curry leaves. Add cooked dal mixture. Simmer for 10 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Oriya dal with vegetables. Simple and nutritious comfort food. Don't overmash the vegetables. Temple cuisine specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Grind mustard seeds, poppy seeds, and green chilies with little water to make paste. Heat mustard oil and add nigella seeds. Add fish pieces and cook for 3 minutes. Add mustard paste, turmeric, and salt. Add little water and simmer for 10 minutes. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali hilsa fish in mustard sauce. The mustard paste should be smooth. Don't overcook hilsa. King of Bengali fish dishes.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix rice flour with salt and water to make soft dough. Mix jaggery, coconut, and sesame seeds for filling. Take portions of dough, flatten, add filling, and seal. Wrap in banana leaves. Steam for 20 minutes until cooked. Serve hot or cold.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Assamese rice cake. Banana leaves impart unique flavor. The filling should be well-mixed. Festival specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat mustard oil and add bay leaves and cardamom. Add onions and cook until deep golden. Add ginger-garlic paste and all spices. Cook for 5 minutes. Add mutton and cook on high heat for 15 minutes. Reduce heat and cook covered for 40 minutes until tender. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice or luchi.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali slow-cooked mutton. Cook on high heat initially for kosha effect. The gravy should be thick and dark. Sunday special dish.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat oil and add fish pieces. Cook until done. Remove fish and mash. In same pan, add potatoes, tomato, green chilies, ginger, turmeric, and ngari. Mash everything together. Add mashed fish and mix well. Cook for 5 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with coriander. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Manipuri mashed curry. Ngari gives unique fermented flavor. Everything should be well-mashed. Comfort food from Northeast.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mash chhena well until smooth. Add sugar, semolina, nuts, raisins, and cardamom. Mix well. Grease baking dish with ghee. Pour mixture and spread evenly. Bake at 350°F for 45 minutes until golden brown. Cool completely before cutting. Serve at room temperature.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Oriya baked cheese cake. The chhena should be very fresh. Bake until golden for authentic flavor. Famous Odisha sweet.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat milk and add lemon juice to curdle. Strain and wash chhena under cold water. Knead chhena until smooth. Make small balls. Boil sugar and water to make syrup. Add cardamom. Add chhena balls to boiling syrup. Pressure cook for 2 whistles. Cool completely. Serve chilled.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali spongy sweet. Knead chhena well for smooth texture. Don't open pressure cooker immediately. Perfect dessert for celebrations.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat mustard oil and add vegetables with turmeric. Cook until tender. Add khar, ginger, and green chilies. Simmer for 10 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Assamese alkaline curry. Khar gives unique flavor and health benefits. Use fresh seasonal vegetables. Beginning of every Assamese meal.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat mustard oil and add bay leaf. Add onions and cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste and all spices. Cook for 3 minutes. Add prawns and cook for 5 minutes. Add coconut milk and green chilies. Simmer for 8 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali prawn curry with coconut milk. Don't overcook prawns. The curry should be creamy. Special occasion dish.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak cooked rice in water overnight. Add yogurt, salt, cumin seeds, green chilies, and ginger. Mix well. Garnish with cilantro. Serve chilled with fried vegetables and pickles.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Oriya fermented rice. Perfect summer food. The rice should be well-fermented. Cooling and nutritious meal.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat oil and add vegetables with turmeric. Cook until tender. Add ginger, green chilies, and ngari if using. Simmer for 5 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Manipuri vegetable stew. Very simple and healthy preparation. Use seasonal vegetables. Light and nutritious.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat mustard oil and add bay leaf. Add onions and cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste and all spices. Cook for 3 minutes. Add fish pieces and cook for 5 minutes. Add yogurt and green chilies. Simmer for 10 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali fish in yogurt curry. Don't let yogurt curdle. The curry should be creamy. Bengali comfort food.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mash boiled potatoes coarsely. Add green chilies, ginger, onion, mustard oil, and salt. Mix well. Garnish with cilantro. Serve at room temperature with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Assamese mashed potato. Don't mash too smooth. Mustard oil gives authentic flavor. Simple comfort food.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat mustard oil and add panch phoron. Add potatoes and fry lightly. Add onions and cook until golden. Add ginger paste, turmeric, and chili powder. Cook for 2 minutes. Add fish pieces and green chilies. Add water and simmer for 12 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali everyday fish curry. Light and flavorful. The gravy should be thin. Perfect with steamed rice.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Cook rice in milk until very soft and creamy. Add sugar and cook until dissolved. Heat ghee and fry nuts and raisins. Add to kheer with cardamom. Simmer for 5 minutes. Serve hot or cold.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Oriya rice pudding. The rice should be well-cooked and creamy. Perfect for festivals. Can be served hot or cold.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat mustard oil and add mustard seeds. Add bamboo shoots, ginger, green chilies, and turmeric. Cook for 15 minutes until tender. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Assamese bamboo shoot curry. Use fresh bamboo shoots if available. Unique flavor of Northeast. Healthy and nutritious.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Knead chhena until smooth. Heat ghee in pan and add chhena. Cook on low heat for 5 minutes. Add sugar and cardamom. Cook until mixture thickens. Remove from heat and cool slightly. Shape into desired forms or press in molds. Garnish with pistachios. Refrigerate for 1 hour before serving.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali milk sweet. The chhena should be very fresh. Don't overcook to prevent graininess. Perfect for festivals.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Make dough with flour, water, and salt. Rest for 30 minutes. For filling, mix chicken with onion, garlic, ginger, chilies, soy sauce, oil, salt, and pepper. Roll dough into small circles. Place filling in center and pleat edges to seal. Steam for 15 minutes until cooked. Serve hot with spicy sauce.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Sikkim steamed dumplings. Seal edges properly to prevent opening. Steam on high heat. Popular Northeast snack.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat oil and add onions. Cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and green chilies. Cook for 3 minutes. Add pork pieces and cook for 15 minutes. Add fermented soybean paste, turmeric, and salt. Cover and cook for 40 minutes until pork is tender. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Nagaland pork curry. Fermented soybean paste gives unique flavor. Cook until pork is very tender. Authentic Northeast cuisine.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat oil and add onions. Cook until golden. Add garlic, ginger, and green chilies. Cook for 3 minutes. Add pork pieces and cook for 10 minutes. Add rice, turmeric, water, and salt. Cover and cook for 25 minutes until rice is done. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Meghalaya rice and pork dish. Cook rice and pork together for unified flavor. One-pot meal from Northeast. Comfort food.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat oil and add vegetables with turmeric. Cook until tender. Add ginger, green chilies, and fermented fish paste if using. Simmer for 8 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Mizoram vegetable stew. Use seasonal vegetables. Light and healthy preparation. Staple Northeast dish.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat milk and add lemon juice to curdle. Strain and wash chhena under cold water. Knead chhena until very smooth. Make small balls. Boil sugar and water to make syrup. Add cardamom and rose water. Add chhena balls to boiling syrup. Pressure cook for 2 whistles. Cool completely. Serve chilled.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali spongy sweet. Knead chhena for 10 minutes for best texture. The balls should be perfectly round. Famous Bengali dessert.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat oil and add onions. Cook until translucent. Add garlic, ginger, and green chilies. Cook for 2 minutes. Add chicken and cook for 8 minutes. Add broth, soy sauce, salt, and pepper. Bring to boil. Add noodles and cook for 5 minutes. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Arunachal noodle soup. Use fresh noodles if available. The broth should be flavorful. Comfort food from mountains.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat oil and add vegetables with turmeric. Cook until tender. Add dried fish powder, ginger, and green chilies. Simmer for 10 minutes. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Tripura vegetable curry. Dried fish powder gives unique flavor. Use local vegetables. Tribal cuisine specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat mustard oil and add bay leaf. Add onions and cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, and all spices. Cook for 5 minutes. Add fish pieces and green chilies. Cook for 12 minutes until fish is done. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bengali rich fish curry. The gravy should be thick and flavorful. Don't overcook fish. Special occasion dish.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat mustard oil and add onions. Cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste and all spices. Cook for 5 minutes. Add duck pieces and cook for 15 minutes. Add green chilies and cover. Cook for 40 minutes until duck is tender. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with rice.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Assamese duck curry. Duck takes longer to cook than chicken. The meat should be very tender. Rich and flavorful.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak Bengal gram and rice for 4 hours. Grind with green chilies, ginger, turmeric, salt, and little water to make thick batter. Pour into greased steamer plates. Steam for 20 minutes until cooked. Cut into pieces and serve hot with chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Chhattisgarhi steamed lentil cake. The batter should be thick but pourable. Steam on high heat. Healthy and nutritious.

ingredients: For Poha: 2 cups thick poha (flattened rice)
Indian.cooking_instructions: For Poha: Rinse poha and drain. Heat oil and add mustard seeds, curry leaves, onions, chilies, and ginger. Add peanuts, turmeric, salt, and sugar. Add poha and mix gently. For Jalebi: Make batter with flour and yogurt. Ferment for 8 hours. Make sugar syrup. Fry jalebi spirals and dip in syrup. Serve poha with hot jalebi.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional MP breakfast combination. Poha should be soft but not mushy. Jalebi should be crispy and syrupy. Perfect breakfast duo.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat oil and add onions. Cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste and tomatoes. Cook until soft. Add all spices and cook for 3 minutes. Add potatoes and mix well. Cover and cook for 15 minutes until potatoes are tender. Season with salt. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot with roti.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bundelkhand potato tomato curry. Simple and rustic flavors. Cook until potatoes are soft. Comfort food from Central India.

ingredients: For Dal: 1/2 cup split yellow lentils
Indian.cooking_instructions: For Bafla: Mix flour, semolina, ghee, and salt. Add water to make stiff dough. Shape into balls and boil for 20 minutes. Then bake at 350°F for 15 minutes. For Dal: Pressure cook lentils for 3 whistles. Heat ghee and add onions. Cook until golden. Add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, and spices. Add cooked dal and simmer. Serve hot bafla with dal and ghee.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Malwa wheat balls with dal. Bafla should be firm and well-cooked. The dal should be thick. Similar to Rajasthani dal baati but unique to Malwa region.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Mix rice flour with water, onion, chilies, ginger, cilantro, turmeric, and salt to make smooth batter. Heat pan and pour batter to make thin pancake. Cook until golden on both sides. Serve hot with chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Chhattisgarhi rice pancake. The batter should be smooth and pourable. Cook on medium heat. Simple breakfast dish.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Heat ghee and add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, and curry leaves. Add ginger and green chilies. Add grated corn and cook for 5 minutes. Add milk, salt, and sugar. Cook until mixture thickens. Garnish with cilantro. Serve hot.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional MP corn dish. Use fresh tender corn for best taste. The mixture should be creamy. Popular street food from Indore.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Cook rice in milk until very soft and creamy. Add jaggery and cook until dissolved. Heat ghee and fry nuts and raisins. Add to kheer with cardamom. Simmer for 5 minutes. Serve hot or cold.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Bundelkhand rice pudding with jaggery. The rice should be well-cooked and creamy. Jaggery gives unique flavor. Festival specialty.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak lentils for 3 hours. Grind coarsely with green chilies, ginger, curry leaves, and salt. Don't add water while grinding. Shape into balls and deep fry until golden. Serve hot topped with yogurt, butter, cumin powder, and cilantro.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Malwa fried lentil balls. The batter should be fluffy and coarse. Serve immediately with toppings. Rich and indulgent.

ingredients: For Filling: 1 cup mixed vegetables, chopped
Indian.cooking_instructions: Make dough with rice flour, water, and salt. For filling, heat oil and cook vegetables with ginger-garlic paste and spices. Cool completely. Take portions of dough, flatten, add filling, and seal. Steam for 25 minutes until cooked. Serve hot with chutney.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional Chhattisgarhi steamed rice dumplings. The dough should be soft and pliable. Seal edges properly. Healthy steamed snack.

Indian.cooking_instructions: Soak sabudana for 4 hours and drain. Heat ghee and add cumin seeds and curry leaves. Add potatoes and cook until tender. Add ginger, green chilies, and peanuts. Add sabudana and salt. Cook for 5 minutes, stirring gently. Garnish with cilantro and lemon juice. Serve hot.
Indian.chef_tips: Traditional MP fasting food. Sabudana should be well-soaked but not mushy. Cook gently to prevent sticking. Perfect for festivals.
